content:
• Wednesday, August 28, 2013

  • After-hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: PRCP +25%. GES +18%. GAME +4%. AUQ +4%. REDF +4%.
    • Top losers: TFM -3%. OCN -2%. ALNY -2%. CLB -2%. SVXY -2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:39 PM
  • GES

    Guess soars as earnings, revenue top estimates

    • Shares of Guess (NYSE:GES) are moving sharply higher AH as the company turns in a big top and bottom line beat for Q2.
    • Net revenue decreases 0.5% and 1.5% in North America and Asia respectively while sales rise 1.4% in Europe.
    • North American retail comps growth comes in at -2%.
    • Operating earnings rise 16.8% while operating margin expands 150 bps.
    • FY14 outlook: EPS of $1.78-1.92 on revenue of $2.56-2.59B versus consensus of $1.79/ share on $2.58B in sales. Q3 outlook: EPS of $0.34-0.38 on revenue of $610-620M against consensus of $0.40/ share on sales of $614.98M. (PR)
    • Shares +18% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:39 PM
  • GAME

    More on Shanda Games Q2 results, guidance

    • Shanda Games (GAME +3.2%) shares have cooled off AH and are now up 1.1%. GAME was up as much as 6.6% AH following the company's Q2 results.
    • The MMO segment saw a 1.5% Q/Q increase in MAU to 18.9M, a 5.2% decrease in MPU to 3.2M, and a 4.7% increase in ARPU to RMB98. The mobile unit's DAU expanded 32.4% Q/Q to 400K. ARDAU decreased 28.6% to RMB2.8 due to lower "Million Arthur" in-game item sales in Korea and Taiwan.
    • Management guides for Q3 revenue of $180.9M-$182.6M (consensus of $183.3M). Mobile game revenue is expected to grow 50% Q/Q and account for 10% of revenue, driven by strength in the "Million Arthur" game.
    • Shanda expects gross and operating margins of 71%-72% and 42%-43% in Q3. Excluding the effect of the poorly-received acquisition of platform-related affiliates in July, gross margin is expected to be 63%-64% (64.6% in Q2) and operating margin is expected to "decline modestly" from 30.1% in Q2.
    • Conference call scheduled for 9pm ET
     
     
     
     
    | 4:57 PM
  • TFM

    The Fresh Market slips as guidance fails to wow

    • The Fresh Market (NASDAQ:TFM) falls 2.4% AH following the company's Q2 report.
    • Comps growth comes in at 3.4% for the period (1.8% increase in number of transactions, 1.6% increase in average transaction size).
    • Gross margin expands by 10 bps.
    • Operating margin expands 40 bps.
    • FY13 outlook: 21-22 new stores; $120-140M in capex; comps growth of 3-4.5%, EPS of $1.50-1.55. Consensus EPS estimate is $1.59/ share. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:56 PM
  • GAME

    Shanda Games beats by $0.04, beats on revenue

    • Shanda Games (NASDAQ:GAME): Q2 EPS of $0.24 beats by $0.04.
    • Revenue of $175.6M beats by $0.86M. Shares +6.59% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:34 PM
  • TFM

    The Fresh Market EPS in-line, misses on revenue

    • The Fresh Market (NASDAQ:TFM): Q2 EPS of $0.32 in-line.
    • Revenue of $354.8M (+13.3% Y/Y) misses by $2.28M. Shares -1.09% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:24 PM
  • SWS

    SWS Group EPS -$0.99

    • SWS Group (NYSE:SWS): FQ4 EPS of -$0.99 may not be comparable to consensus of $-0.5
    • Revenue of $55.4M beats by $. Shares +1.83% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:18 PM
  • EGAN

    eGain beats by $0.09, beats on revenue

    • eGain (NASDAQ:EGAN): FQ4 EPS of $0.07 beats by $0.09.
    • Revenue of $18.0M beats by $3.5M. Shares +1.85% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:12 PM
  • GES

    Guess? beats by $0.17, beats on revenue

    • Guess? (NYSE:GES): Q2 EPS of $0.52 beats by $0.17.
    • Revenue of $639M beats by $13.85M. Shares +14.46% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:09 PM
  • SEAS

    SeaWorld plunges on price cut report

    • Bloomberg reports SeaWorld (SEAS -6.2%) has cut prices in the wake of its disappointing Q2 results and full-year guidance cut. Shares dove just before the close.
    • SeaWorld is also contending with the PR hit delivered by the documentary Blackfish, which covers the treatment of whales in captivity.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:09 PM
  • DY

    Dycom upgraded to Buy at DA Davidson

    • Dycom Industries (DY -5.4%) finishes in the red today, but off intra-day lows after DA Davidson upgraded the shares mid-day from Neutral to Buy and raises its price target from $26 to $30.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:07 PM
  • ARTX

    Arotech Simulation Division wins $2.2M in contract orders

    • Arotech Corporation (ARTX -5.5%) slips today in spite of saying its simulation division has won an additional $2.2M in contracts awards and modifications to previous awarded contracts.
    • These awards are in addition to the recently-announced $1.67M award from the California Commission on Peace Officer Standards and Training.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:46 PM
  • AFFY

    Affymax sinks after article questions Omontys prospects

    • Shares of Affymax (OTC:AFFY -12.4%) — which ran square into a brick wall earlier this year after the recall of the anemia drug Omontys — sell-off sharply as SA contributor Alpha Exposure calls the stock "likely worthless" in an article published around midday.
    • "Too many stars would have to align" for the drug to make a comeback, Alpha Exposure says, before listing seven steps which would define "the road back."
    • The author lists a whole host of other concerns and calls the bull case "far fetched."
    • By contrast, SA contributor EXPstocktrader — who, according to one article has spent "120-150 hours" researching "this special situation" — is "highly confident that Omontys will return to the market under a new label based on the fact that 3 fatalities out of 25,000 is considered statistically insignificant."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:42 PM | 3 Comments
  • BP

    Reuters: BP set to sign deal to revive Iraq's Kirkuk oilfield

    • BP (BP +1.6%) expects to sign an initial deal in early September to revive Iraq's northern Kirkuk oilfield, which it hopes will enable it to negotiate access to the significant reserves in northern Iraq, Reuters reports.
    • "It's an initial 18-month deal to offer support, which will provide an opportunity for BP to negotiate a longer-term development contract," says a source familiar with the negotiations.
    • BP could have the best relationship with Baghdad among the world's global oil companies due to its contract at the $30B Rumaila oilfield project. (earlier)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:29 PM
  • XCRA

    LTX-Credence slides on underwhelming guidance

    • Shares of LTX-Credence (LTXC -12.3%) slid after management announced underwhelming FQ1 guidance. Revenue is expected to be $31M-$35M vs. a consensus $45.7M. EPS is expected to be -$0.14 to -$0.09 vs. a consensus $0.05.
    • Craig-Hallum's Christian Schwab on the conference call: "What gives you some confidence in ’14 being the growth year?"
    • Previous: LTX-Credence EPS in-line, misses on revenues
     
     
     
     
    | 3:28 PM
  • EDAP

    EDAP slips as Q2 revenue comes in below estimates

    • EDAP (EDAP -5.7%) slips after its Q2 sales missed estimates earlier today.
    • HIFU revenue was €967K ($1.3M), compared to €1.1M($1.4) for the same period last year.
    • Lithotripsy division sales were €3.5M ($4.6M), compared to €5M ($6.4M) during the year ago period.
    • Just eight lithotripsy machines were sold during the quarter, comprised of five Sonolith i-move devices and three Sonolith Praktis devices, compared to a total of fourteen devices sold in Q212.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:27 PM | 3 Comments
  • WSM

    Williams-Sonoma reports strong sales

    • A strong quarter for housing filtered down to help lift results for Williams-Sonoma (WSM -1.2%) during Q2.
    • Brand revenue growth: Pottery Barn +9.9%; Williams-Sonoma -0.4%; Pottery Barn Kids +8.2%; West Elm +16.5%; PBteen +16.3%.
    • Direct to customer sales rose 15.3% to $478M
    • The retailer raised its FY13 revenue guidance to $4.26B-$4.34B vs. $4.28B consensus. (PR)
    • Shares have resumed trading after a short halt.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:16 PM
  • INSM

    Leerink positive on Insmed, sees opportunity for Arikace in NTM

    • Leerink has done some investigating and analyst Joseph Schwartz is now "more bullish on Arikace's ability to generate an approvable portfolio of clinical data."
    • That's good news for Insmed (INSM +5.2%) shareholders who took a big hit around the first of July after Phase 3 trial results suggested Novartis' Tobi performed better on lung function tests.
    • Schwartz likes the prospects for Arikace in non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) lung disease, which is where UBS identified an "underappreciated opportunity" back in June.
    • "The clinical relevance of TARGET's secondary endpoints, and the seriousness of the NTM cases afflicting TARGET's patient population ... could lower the bar for trial success," Schwartz says, referring to an ongoing trial of Arikace in NTM.
    • Price target reiterated at $22.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:02 PM
  • NFX

    Two Malaysian-based firms added to bidders for Newfield's Asia assets

    • Malaysia-based SapuraKencana and Petrofac are among companies selected for second round bidding for Newfield Exploration's (NFX +3.1%) $2B in oil and gas assets in Malaysia and China, according to local reports.
    • NFX's advisor Goldman Sachs earlier had shortlisted Exxon Mobil (NYSE:XOM), Royal Dutch Shell (RDS.A, RDS.B), Talisman Energy (NYSE:TLM) and Kuwait's state-run exploration company to submit second round bids, which will close Sept. 26.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:47 PM
  • COP

    ConocoPhillips comes out ahead in lackluster western Gulf lease sale

    • ConocoPhillips (COP +1.5%) submitted the highest bid on a single tract in today's lease sale of drilling rights in the western Gulf of Mexico, a $30.6M offer for Alaminos Canyon block 475, ~60 miles from Shell's (RDS.A, RDS.B) Perdido platform.
    • New geological data captured last summer drove competition for the Alaminos drilling leases; the frenzy of bidding on block 475 suggests companies liked what the seismic surveys showed below an underground layer of salt in the region.
    • COP also submitted the most in high bids - $50.3M for 29 tracts; the Gulf’s largest leaseholder, BP, opted out of the sale.
    • The sale netted ~$102M on 61 total bids, the area's second-lowest number of bids since 1983.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:33 PM
  • CLF

    Cliffs Natural Resources +3% on AK Steel contract

    • Cliffs Natural Resources (CLF +2.9%) powers higher after announcing a new agreement with AK Steel (NYSE:AKS) to supply the steelmaker with iron ore pellets from 2014 through 2023.
    • Credit Suisse remains bearish on CLF but a bit less so, encouraged that the company continues to make progress on contract renewals with customers; the firm also says it looks likely that CLF’s response to new entrants in the core Great Lakes market will be price- and not volume-related, a positive. (earlier)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:10 PM
  • ENTR

    Entropic jumps after announcing Chinese set-top win

    • Chinese OEM Jiuzhou is using an Entropic (ENTR +5.8%) Ethernet-over-coax home networking chip and related software in its HD set-tops. (PR)
    • Entropic has been in need of some good news after getting clobbered at the beginning of the month due to the poor Q3 guidance (blamed on sales delays/slowdowns involving U.S. pay-TV providers) provided with a Q2 beat.
    • CEO Patrick Henry bought 10K shares on Aug. 8.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:10 PM
  • CREE

    Cree, industry peers rally following bullish analyst notes

    • Piper is reiterating an Overweight and $70 PT for Cree (CREE +5.5%), and says survey data points to strong consumer willingness in paying a premium for LED bulbs on account of their energy efficiency and quality.
    • UBS reports Chinese LED demand is strong.
    • LED wafer vendor Rubicon (RBCN +4%) and equipment supplier GT Advanced (GTAT +2.4%) are also rallying.
    • Cree was hammered earlier this month after missing FQ4 revenue estimates, providing light guidance, and reporting a lower-than-expected gross margin (due to the introduction of cheaper LED bulbs).
     
     
     
     
    | 1:52 PM
  • IMGN

    ImmunoGen in potential $200.5M licensing deal with Eli Lilly

    • ImmunoGen (IMGN +2.6%) spikes after an 8-K filed today shows the company has entered into a licensing agreement with Eli Lilly (LLY +0.6%).
    • Under the terms of the deal, LLY is granted exclusive use of IMGN's maytansinoid-based TAP technology to create and market "products directed to a specific antigen target."
    • IMGN is entitled to receive as much as $200.5M in milestone-related payments plus royalties on any future commercial sales. (8-K)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:39 PM
  • EAC

    Erickson Air-Crane wins a contract with the city of Los Angeles to provide aerial fire fighting services

    • Erickson Air-Crane (EAC +2%) wins a contract to provide Los Angeles County with aerial firefighting services and standby availability under a deal worth approximately $2.7M per year.
    • It's a three-year agreement with two optional years thereafter.
    • Currently, EAC is actively engaged in fighting the Rim fire in California, which is at present the largest wildfire in the country.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:35 PM | 1 Comment
  • ARAY

    Brean upbeat on Accuray

    • Accuray (ARAY +10%) is up sharply on the session following Tuesday's FQ4 results.
    • Brean's Jason Wittes maintains a Buy on the shares citing the likelihood that the company's backlog "will continue to improve next year."
    • "Net order rates in FQ413 came in at ~$58 million (gross of ~$72 million), beating our estimate of ~$50 million and growing 32% from FQ313," Wittes adds.
    • Brean's price target is $9, above Jefferies' new target of $8, disclosed in a note released earlier today.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:29 PM
  • LMAT

    LeMaitre Vascular buys assets of InaVein for $2.5M

    • LeMaitre Vascular (LMAT +2.3%) says it's acquired the assets of InaVein for $2.5M.
    • The purchase price represents 1.1X of InaVein's 2012 sales, and potential earn-out payments in 2014 and 2015 based on the performance of the acquired business and regulatory approval in China.
    • InaVein owned and marketed the TRIVEX System, which carries an attractive 60% - 70% gross margin.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:19 PM
  • CRUS

    Feltl upgrade gives boost to Cirrus Logic

    • In addition to Avago's numbers, Cirrus Logic (CRUS +7.7%) is benefiting from an upgrade to Buy from Feltl's Jeff Schreiner.
    • Schreiner, who has lifted his PT to $26 from $20, declares Cirrus undervalued on account of its non-Apple opportunities, such as the potential for non-iPhone smartphone wins for a new analog-to-digital converter for microphones.
    • Cirrus remains down 24% YTD, and more than 50% below its 52-week high of $45.49.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:03 PM
  • CIEN

    Cyan rallies following bullish SA Pro article

    • In an SA Pro column (embargoed until 9:30AM tomorrow), Stephen Simpson argues Cyan (CYNI +4.9%) is capable of delivering a 20% CAGR through 2022 on the back of strong demand for its packet-optical systems (they combine Ethernet switching and optical transmission systems) and carrier software-defined networking (SDN) platform.
    • Simpsons observes Cyan had 85 customers for its Blue Planet SDN platform (still less than 10% of revenue) at the end of Q2, up from the 35 going into its IPO, and that the company's hardware addresses an $18.5B/year market opportunity.
    • However, he cautions Cyan remains dependent on telco Windstream (37% of Q2 revenue), and that competition is fierce. Cisco, Ciena, and Tellabs are major players in the packet-optical space, and Cisco and Huawei are among the companies working on carrier SDN solutions.
    • Cyan remains 14% below its May IPO price of $11.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM

  • Energy stocks surging now, but RJ's Molchanov says it won't last

    • The energy sector (XLE +1.9%) is enjoying a boost from rising oil prices (USO +0.9%), but Raymond James analyst Pavel Molchanov doubts the gains can last, pointing to similar fears in 2003 and 2011.
    • In the run-up to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, oil prices rose steadily and peaked a few days before the invasion but then began to slide; 60 days after the invasion, prices were 23% lower than at the peak.
    • A similar pattern is seen in the 2011 NATO intervention in Libya, as prices rose for a month after NATO airstrikes began but then rolled over; after 60 days, prices were 14% lower than at the peak.
    • Ben Levisohn of Barron's calculates XLE fell ~4.9% in the 60 trading days after the start of the airstrikes on Libya.
    • ETFs: ERX, VDE, DIG, UCO, OIL, BNO.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM

  • Midday top 10 gainers / Losers

    • Midday top 10 gainers: ANLY +60%. ASTX +23%. ZLC +22%. ADEP +21%. OTIV +21%. KEQU +17%. BIOF +16%. PRGN +14%. MTEX +13%. HMNY +12%.
    • Midday top 10 Losers: PTGI -68%. LAS -14%. AMAP -13%. CPRX -12%. PRAN -12%. CREG -12%. GIG -11%. LTXC -11%. FRO -11%. CHOP -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM
  • ASTX

    Astex Pharmaceutical takes another leg higher on positive Phase II trial results for SGI-110

    • Astex Pharmaceutical (NASDAQ:ASTX) continues to run, now up more than 23% following positive topline results from Phase II trials of its SGI-110 drug candidate in patients with acute myelogenous leukemia and myelodysplastic syndromes.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:27 PM
  • TYG

    Tortoise Energy upgraded to Buy at Stifel, shares rise

    • Tortoise Energy Infrastructure (TYG +1.8%) is upgraded to Buy from Hold with a $47 price target at Stifel Nicolaus following a strong quarterly report.
    • TYG reported total distributable cash flow of $18.1M vs. $16.4M in the prior year, 1.11x the current payout of $0.57/share.
    • The firm estimates current NAV of ~$41.82 and an adjusted NAV, which gives effect for tax deferred liability, of ~$47.18; thus the firm believes shares trade at 94.4% to its adjusted NAV.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:27 PM
  • LNVGY

    BlackBerry jumps on fresh Lenovo rumors

    • Rumors Lenovo (OTCPK:LNVGY) will make a $17/share bid for BlackBerry (BBRY +5.3%) are fueling a rally in the latter company's shares.
    • BlackBerry shares have already soared more than once this year on Lenovo speculation (I, II) that didn't pan out. But that was before the company began formally evaluating "strategic alternatives" widely believed to include a sale.
    • The fact Lenovo's market cap only stands at $10B means acquiring BlackBerry in full wouldn't be easy, should the Chinese PC/smartphone giant be interested.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:14 PM | 53 Comments
  • KEYW

    KEYW Holding lands $75M cyber training contract

    • KEYW Corporation (KEYW +1%) says it's landed a contract to provide advanced cyber training content development, delivery, and lifecycle support to an undiclosed U.S. based customer.
    • The contract comprises a five-year ordering period totaling over $75M.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:06 PM
  • MRO

    Energy, gold stocks among sector leaders as Syria weighs

    • Energy stocks (XLE +1.9%) lead the way this session as West Texas crude tests $110, with tensions over Syria continuing to feed Middle East supply concerns; Syria concerns and Libyan export cuts are trumping the bearish influence from a surprise gain for U.S. crude supplies.
    • Among sector leaders: MRO +3.3%, EOG +3.1%, CVX +2.5%, TOT +2.4%, WLL +2.4%, APC +2.2%, RDS.A +2.1%, XOM +2.1%, HAL +2%, SLB +2%, COP +1.8%, PSX +1.7%, BP +1.6%, APA +1.6%, HES +1.5%, KOG +1.3%.
    • ETFs: ERX, VDE, DIG, IEO, IEZ, IYE, PXE, PXI, XES, XOP, RYE, FXN, OIH, PXJ, PSCE, ERY, DUG, DDG, FRAK.
    • After big losses yesterday, gold miners (GDX +2.4%) are strong today despite only a slight gain in the metal.
    • Miners: ABX +3.6%, GG +3.2%, NEM +2.2%, KGC +2%, SLW +2%, GFI +1.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:59 AM | 1 Comment
  • DY

    Dycom tumbles after FQ4 results

    • Dycom Industries (DY -8.5%) falls after reporting FQ4 results Tuesday evening.
    • Organic contract growth for the period was 7.5%, while total revenue (includes businesses acquired) came in ahead of the Street and ahead of the high end of company guidance.
    • Q1 2014 outlook: EPS of $0.42-0.49 on revenue of $475-495M against consensus of $0.47/ share on $471.5M in revenue. (PR)
    • See also: DY announces new buyback plan
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM | 1 Comment
  • ISR

    IsoRay announces offering, shares sink

    • IsoRay (ISR -13.7%) plunges after announcing an offering of common stock and convertible preferred shares.
    • ISR will issue 3.8M shares of its common at $0.55 each, preferred shares convertible into 3.1M common shares, and warrants (18 month term, exercisable six months post-offering at offering price) for the purchase of an additional 5.6M shares.
    • Total proceeds are expected to be $3.8M ($6.9M if the warrants are exercised). (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:40 AM
  • IGTE

    iGATE rises on Sidoti upgrade, CEO speculation

    • Shares of iGATE (IGTE +7.8%) are rising after Sidoti upgrades shares to Buy from Neutral and hikes its PT to $28 from $22.
    • Also in the mix - speculation is brewing that Infosys's recently-resigned Americas head Ashok Vemuri may be gunning for the CEO job at iGATE. iGATE fired CEO Phaneesh Murthy back in May.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:35 AM
  • EQNR

    Statoil upgraded to Buy at BAML, shares rise

    • Statoil (STO +3.7%) is upgraded to Buy from Neutral with a $25 price target, up from $23, at BofA/Merrill after yesterday's announcement of the Bay du Nord discovery off eastern Canada.
    • BAML likes STO's "sensible strategy" of targeting modest production growth, balanced with respectable return investments carrying relatively low execution and political risk.
    • Investors need patience before true earnings potential of STO's projects becomes apparent, but $18B of recent disposals shows the inherent value as well as management's commitment to shareholders.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:35 AM
  • OTIV

    Court denies T-Mobile's Markman request in On Track Innovations' patent suit

    • Shares of On Track Innovations (OTIV +14.5%) continue to climb higher after the company announces that the Southern District Court of New York has denied T-Mobile's request for reconsideration of the court's Markman decision. The decision adopted OTIV's proposed definitions of all disputed terms.
    • The patent infringement lawsuit relates to Near Field Communication tech used in phones sold by T-Mobile. The case was filed in March 2012.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:25 AM
  • KKD

    Shares of Krispy Kreme Doughnut frisky ahead of earnings

    • Krispy Kreme Doughnuts (KKD +2.7%) trades higher in front of in its earnings report scheduled to be released after market close tomorrow.
    • The company has beat estimates in 3 of the last 4 quarters and earnings whispers have sounded positive that the streak could go to 4 out of 5.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:25 AM
  • HNR

    Harvest Natural -4% on negative Seeking Alpha article

    • Today's drop in Harvest Natural Resources (HNR -4.1%) is attributed to a negative article on Seeking Alpha, which predicts a 40%-100% downside.
    • The recent run in HNR shares belies the company's aggressive accounting and lack of revenue, according to the anonymous fund manager who wrote the article.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:23 AM
  • QIHU

    Qihoo dives after pricing $550M debt offering; Sohu pops on Sogou hopes

    • Qihoo's (QIHU -6.6%) 2018 convertible notes carry an interest rate of 2.5%, and a conversion price of $110.96 (51% above current levels). (PR)
    • Goldman estimated (before the deal was priced) the offering would dilute EPS by 4%-6%. The firm thinks Qihoo will use the proceeds " to strengthen its presence in the key strategic areas, such as in mobile gaming and search," to counter the expansion efforts of rivals.
    • Judging by today's rally in Sohu (SOHU +4.7%) shares, some investors are clearly betting Qihoo will use the funds to strengthen its search presence by acquiring Sohu's Sogou unit, for which Qihoo has already held buyout talks.
    • Previous: Qihoo announces $550M convertible debt offering
     
     
     
     
    | 11:22 AM | 1 Comment
  • HALO

    Halozyme rises, article flags Baker Bros. buy, insider purchase

    • Halozyme Therapeutics (HALO +7.7%) is on the move today, rising markedly in early trading.
    • Perhaps helping the cause is an article from SA contributor StockMatusow who highlights a recent investment by Baker Bros. as well as an open market purchase by a company director.
    • Matusow also flags a purchase of 1,132 September $7.50 strike calls as an indication that someone might "know something."
     
     
     
     
    | 11:17 AM | 2 Comments
  • IQNT

    Inteliquent climbs after releasing delayed Q2 10-Q

    • Shares of Inteliquent (IQNT +5.6%) are climbing after the company filed its delayed 10-Q yesterday afternoon.
    • With seemingly no material differences from the preliminary Q2 results, the arrival of the quarterly filing and the end of the company's accounting probe may be giving investors a chance to breathe easier.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:12 AM
  • ADEP

    Adept Technology jumps after FQ4 results

    • Adept Technology (ADEP +19.6%) soars after reporting a 25% sequential increase in revenue and a 330 bps Q/Q improvement in gross margin.
    • The company's operating loss also narrowed considerably during the quarter.
    • EBITDA was positive ($186K) versus an adjusted EBITDA loss of $1.1M in FQ3.
    • "Fiscal 2013 was a year of transition for Adept, in which we embarked on a major restructuring. Our efforts have yielded initial favorable results, as we begin to stabilize and grow the business," CEO Rob Cain says. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:02 AM
  • BP

    Judge rejects BP's latest bid to stop settlement payments

    • A federal judge denies BP’s (BP +1.7%) latest request for an injunction to halt payments from its multibillion-dollar settlement with victims of the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill.
    • The judge's order says an internal probe by the claims administrator's office didn't find credible evidence of fraud involving employees of the settlement program's claims center in Mobile, Ala.
    • Meanwhile, federal prosecutors charge seven Hooters employees for fraudulent oil spill claims.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:57 AM | 1 Comment
  • OTIV

    On Track Innovations rebounds on insider purchases

    • On Track Innovations (OTIV +9.7%) bounces up following its announcement that several board members have purchased 735K shares pursuant to Rule 10b5-1 plans executed in June and/or OTIV's open trading window policy.
    • Owners will report holdings starting Jan. 1 when OTIV begins to report as a domestic issuer.
    • Previous: On Track Innovations whipsaws on Q2 results
     
     
     
     
    | 10:52 AM
  • AUXL

    Summer Street weighs in on the FDA's delay of Auxilium's PDUFA date for Xiaflex; advises caution

  • SWKS

    RF chipmakers, Apple suppliers rally in sympathy with Avago

    • RF component makers Skyworks (SWKS +2.7%), RF Micro (RFMD +2.9%), TriQuint (TQNT +2.5%), and Anadigics (ANAD +2.8%) are outperforming after peer Avago (AVGO +4%) blew past FQ3 estimates and issued strong FQ4 guidance, while predicting it would get a boost from "very strong product ramps in wireless." Other than Anadigics, all of the aforementioned companies are iPhone suppliers.
    • Non-RF Apple suppliers Cirrus Logic (CRUS +7%), OmniVision (OVTI +2.1%), SanDisk (SNDK +2%), and Nam Tai (NTE +3.2%) are also faring well.
    • On the FQ3 CC, Avago asserted once again the technical demands of 4G radios are helping it gain RF component share, and noted its "two largest smartphone customers" (Apple and Samsung) are ramping next-gen platforms (the iPhone 5S/5C and Galaxy Note 3). Avago says it expects its "content in both these platforms continue to improve substantially."
    • On the wireline/networking side, Avago is upbeat about improving core router demand, the adoption of 40G switches within data centers, CyOptics' sales, and strong 10G/40G optical transceiver demand. The last two are positives for JDSU, FNSR, and NPTN.
    • Goldman, RBC, and Canaccord have hiked their Avago PTs.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:49 AM
  • AMAP

    AutoNavi plunges on Q2 miss, guidance renege

    • Shares of AutoNavi (AMAP -12%) are plunging following a Q2 miss. Management also recanted previous guidance, which it says is "no longer a good indicator of [AutoNavi's] long-term value." The company will instead provide quarterly user metrics. (PR)
    • AutoNavi's free map app reached 137M users and 62M MAU in Q2, compared to 116M/56M in Q1 and 65M/36M in Q2 2012. The company's premium navigation app had been pre-loaded/downloaded on 70M phones and had 3M MAU as of Q2.
    • The mobile map and navigation provider faces increased competition from Baidu, which is expanding its map offerings and now holds 20% of the Chinese mapping market, compared to AutoNavi's 25%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:45 AM

    • Nordic American Tanker (NAT +4.3%) shares push higher after CEO Herbjorn Hansson issues a letter to shareholders saying the company "is in a solid financial condition."

  • E

    Crude production in Libya is sinking fast as protests spread

    • Libyan oil production has dropped to one-eighth of capacity as protests over pay and allegations of corruption spread to fields operated by Eni (E +2.5%) and Repsol (OTCQX:REPYY, OTCQX:REPYF).
    • Earlier protests were in the central and eastern regions that produce and export the majority of Libya’s crude, affecting companies such as Royal Dutch Shell (RDS.A, RDS.B), Marathon Oil (NYSE:MRO), Hess (NYSE:HES) and ConocoPhillips (NYSE:COP).
    • Libyan output has slumped to ~200K bbl/day vs. 640K earlier this month and optimal capacity of 1.6M, according to the chairman of the state oil company.
